musicalLanguage.description: The most famous ragtime piece ever written, and the piece that revived Joplin's legacy when it was featured in The Sting (1973). Ragtime is 'ragged time' — syncopated right-hand melodies over a steady left-hand oom-pah bass. Joplin insisted: 'It is never right to play ragtime fast.'
musicalLanguage.structure: AABBACCDD — classic ragtime multi-strain form. Each strain is 16 bars. The C and D strains modulate to F major (the subdominant).
keyMoments: The iconic opening pickup notes: the most recognized piano intro in ragtime
The B strain: contrasting, more lyrical character
The modulation to F major at the C strain: a lift that changes the whole color
The D strain: the final, most energetic section
teachingGoals: Ragtime left-hand pattern: bass note on 1 and 3, chord on 2 and 4 (oom-pah)
Right-hand syncopation against steady left-hand pulse
Playing at Joplin's intended tempo — moderate, not fast
styleTips: DO NOT play this fast — Joplin was explicit about this
The left hand must be rock steady — it's the timekeeper
Right hand syncopation should feel playful, not frantic
Each strain has its own character — bring out the contrasts
No pedal in ragtime — clean, crisp articulation
